Description: PRESERVING AND IMPROVING ACCESS TO APPALSHOP'S HUMANITIES COLLECTIONS [AS THE ORGANIZATION WORKS TO RESUME HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING, WE ARE SEEKING CAPACITY SUPPORT TO PRESERVE AND IMPROVE ACCESS TO OUR ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS ILLUMINATING THE HISTORY AND CULTURE OF THE APPALACHIAN REGION. FUNDS WILL GO TOWARDS THE DIGITIZATION OF COLLECTIONS THAT ARE IN URGENT NEED OF PRESERVATION MEASURES INCLUDING PHOTONEGATIVE COLLECTIONS SPANNING 1935 TO 1991 AND MOVING IMAGE MATERIALS DATING TO THE 1970S. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO IMPROVE ACCESS TO OUR ROADSIDE THEATER COLLECTION THAT INCLUDES DOCUMENTATION OF LATE-20TH CENTURY GRASSROOTS THEATER MOVEMENTS IN THE U.S.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;TO ENHANCE PUBLIC ACCESS TO ARCHIVED MATERIALS RELATING TO THE HISTORY AND CULTURE OF THE APPALACHIAN REGION.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;DIGITIZATION OF PHOTOGRAPHIC NEGATIVES FROM 1935-1955.&NBSP;DIGITIZATION OF 16MM ARCHIVAL FILM.&NBSP;PURCHASING OF A NEW PHOTO SCANNER&NBSP;AND MOTION FILM SCANNER&NBSP;TO AID IN THE DIGITIZATION EFFORTS.&NBSP;IMPROVING ACCESS TO ROADSIDE THEATER COLLECTION, AN ARCHIVE FOCUSING ON THE HISTORY OF&NBSP;GRASSROOTS THEATER.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE DIGITIZING&NBSP;AND CATALOGUING OF THE ARCHIVE?S COLLECTIONS.&NBSP;&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;ANYONE WITH AN INTEREST IN THE HISTORY OF APPALACHIA. &NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THIS PROJECT DOES NOT&NBSP;INTEND TO ISSUE ANY SUBAWARDS.&NBSP;]

HUMANITIES PROGRAM TO REVITALIZE ECONOMIC AND CIVIC LIFE [LA CASA DEL LIBRO BOOK MUSEUM & SPECIAL LIBRARY (LCDL) SEEKS FUNDING TO RE-INSTALL POSITIONS ADVERSELY IMPACTED BY THE CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIC. LCDL PROPOSES A PROJECT TO IMPROVE COLLECTION ORGANIZATION, STRENGTHEN THE CATALOGING, ENHANCE COLLECTION CARE, AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO OUR HISTORIC COLLECTIONS. LCDL WILL PAY PARTICULAR ATTENTION TO ITS COLLECTIONS THAT EXPLORE AMERICA'S STORY FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF UNDER-REPRESENTED COMMUNITIES DEALING WITH RACIAL JUSTICE AND INEQUALITY. WE WANT TO RESTORE THE FULL-TIME POSITION OF THE SPECIAL COLLECTIONS LIBRARIAN, CREATE A POSITION OF A PART-TIME EDUCATOR TO CONTINUE SHARING THE COLLECTION, CONTINUE THE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM, AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO IT. THE ACTIVITIES GENERATED BY THESE POSITIONS WILL SUPPORT LCDL'S MISSION IN PRESERVING OUR COLLECTIONS AND DELIVERING ACCESS TO CULTURAL EDUCATION.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;TO REHIRE STAFF WITHIN THE&NBSP;SPECIAL COLLECTIONS LIBRARY, AS WELL AS CATALOG, ORGANIZE, AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO ITS UNIQUE COLLECTIONS.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;RESTORING THE FULL-TIME POSITION OF THE SPECIAL COLLECTIONS LIBRARIAN. THE LIBRARIAN WILL CONTINUE THE&NBSP;ORGANIZATION AND CATALOGUING OF THE&NBSP;COLLECTIONS,&NBSP;AND&NBSP;SERVE AS&NBSP;THE POINT OF CONTACT FOR HISTORIANS AND EDUCATORS INTERESTED IN THE HISTORY OF PUERTO RICO.&NBSP;THIS AWARD&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;ALSO&NBSP;CREATE&NBSP;THE POSITION OF A PART-TIME&NBSP;EDUCATOR TO&NBSP;CONTINUE THE LIBRARY'S EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM, WHO WILL PREPARE&NBSP;FOR TWO EXHIBITS ON THE HISTORY OF PUERTO RICO. THE FIRST EXHIBIT WILL BE IN ANTICIPATION OF&NBSP;THE 500TH&NBSP;ANNIVERSARY OF EUROPEAN SETTLEMENT IN&NBSP;SAN JUAN. THE SECOND EXHIBIT&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;FOCUS&NBSP;ON THE ART OF AFRO-PUERTO RICAN ARTIST&NBSP;IMNA&NBSP;ARROYO.&NBSP;&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE CREATION AND RETENTION OF TWO JOBS, AS WELL AS CONTINUING ARCHIVAL WORK WITHIN THE LIBRARY AND THE CREATION OF TWO EXHIBITS.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;PATRONS OF THE ARTS IN SAN JUAN AND NEW YORK CITY, AS WELL AS&NBSP;ANYONE&NBSP;INTERESTED&NBSP;IN THE HISTORY OF&NBSP;THE UNITED STATES&NBSP;FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THIS PROJECT DOES NOT INTEND TO ISSUE ANY SUBAWARDS.&NBSP;]

THE DIGITAL PV PANTHER PROJECT [THE DIGITAL PV PANTHER PROJECT WILL INTRODUCE STUDENTS TO A NETWORK OF PROFESSIONALS. CONSULTANTS, SUCH AS DR. NOEL M. ESTWICK, WILL SHARE THEIR EXPERIENCES AND PROVIDE TRAINING ON GIS STORY-MAPPING, AND THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW STUDENTS TO MEET FREQUENTLY WITH PROFESSORS, ARCHIVISTS, LIBRARIANS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS, CREATING A SPACE OF INTELLECTUAL EXCHANGE THAT INTRODUCES STUDENTS TO A NETWORK IN WHICH THEY CAN PARTICIPATE LONG AFTER THE PROJECT ENDS.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN THREE LIBRARY STAFF POSITIONS AND CREATE TWENTY STUDENT POSITIONS IN SUPPORT OF THE DIGITIZATION OF HISTORICAL MATERIAL FROM THE ARCHIVES OF A HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGE.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: SPECIAL COLLECTIONS AND ARCHIVES DEPARTMENT STAFF AT PRAIRIE VIEW A&M UNIVERSITY WILL LAUNCH THE ?DIGITAL PV PANTHER PROJECT,? FOCUSING ON THE PRESERVATION, DIGITIZATION, RESEARCH, AND DISSEMINATION OF FOUR ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS RELATED TO AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY. STAFF WILL CONDUCT PRESERVATION AND PROCESSING ASSESSMENTS OF THE FOUR COLLECTIONS AND TRAIN STUDENTS IN ARCHIVAL PROCESSING AND RESEARCH. STUDENTS WILL COMPILE NEWSPAPER ARTICLES, BORN-DIGITAL CONTENT, ORAL HISTORIES, MATERIAL CULTURE, AND OTHER MEDIA. STUDENTS WILL ALSO BE INVOLVED IN DIGITAL EXHIBITIONS AND ONLINE CONTENT RELATED TO THE PROJECT, SUCH AS BLOG POSTS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL PARTIALLY SUPPORT THREE LIBRARY STAFF POSITIONS AND EMPLOY TWENTY STUDENTS WHO WILL BE TRAINED IN ARCHIVAL PROCESSING, DIGITIZATION, AND OUTREACH. FOUR ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS WILL BE PROCESSED AND DIGITIZED, AND SELECTED MATERIAL WILL BE SHOWCASED ONLINE.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT STUDENTS, STAFF, FACULTY, AND THE BROADER COMMUNITY AT PRAIRIE VIEW A&M UNIVERSITY, A HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGE.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE PROJECT DOES NOT INTEND TO ISSUE SUBAWARDS.]

PHOENIX ART MUSEUM - LANDSCAPES OF EXTRACTION: THE ART OF MINING IN THE AMERICAN WEST [THE LANDSCAPES OF EXTRACTION EXHIBITION FOCUSES ON THE FIRST HALF OF THE 20TH CENTURY, A PERIOD IN U.S. HISTORY WHEN ARTISTS PORTRAYED REGIONAL THEMES IN THEIR WORK, INSPIRED IN PART BY NEW DEAL PROGRAMS THAT THE GOVERNMENT OPERATED DURING THE ?30S AND EARLY ?40S. LANDSCAPES OF EXTRACTION FEATURES APPROXIMATELY 75 PAINTINGS AND PRINTS FROM MUSEUMS, PRIVATE COLLECTIONS, AND GALLERIES, ACCOMPANIED BY WORKS FROM THE COLLECTION OF PHOENIX ART MUSEUM. THE EXHIBITION HAS A STRONG CONTEMPORARY COMPONENT, A POINT OF VIEW OFTEN DISREGARDED MINING-RELATED SCHOLARSHIP AND COLLECTIONS.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT THE RETENTION OF FOURTEEN STAFF POSITIONS, AND INSTALLATION OF A NEW ART EXHIBITION ABOUT MINING IN THE AMERICAN WEST AT THE PHOENIX ART MUSEUM.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: STAFF AT THE PHOENIX ART MUSEUM WILL INSTALL AN ART EXHIBITION ENTITLED ?LANDSCAPES OF EXTRACTION,? WHICH FOCUSES ON MINING AS A TRANSFORMATIVE INDUSTRY IN THE AMERICAN WEST. STAFF WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT THE EXHIBITION, DEVELOP AND PUBLISH AN ASSOCIATED CATALOG, AND CREATE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AROUND THE EXHIBITION, INCLUDING PUBLIC LECTURES.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL PARTIALLY SUPPORT A TOTAL OF FOURTEEN STAFF POSITIONS CRITICAL TO THE EXHIBITION DESIGN, PREPARATION, AND COLLECTION MANAGEMENT. THE PHOENIX ART MUSEUM ANTICIPATES THAT AT LEAST 25,000 PATRONS WILL VIEW THE EXHIBITION AND PARTICIPATE IN VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PHOENIX ART MUSEUM SERVES THE RESIDENTS AND VISITORS OF THE GREATER PHOENIX METROPOLITAN AREA.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE PROJECT DOES NOT INTEND TO ISSUE SUBAWARDS.]

HIRING AND TRAINING NEW RESTORATION CRAFTSPERSONS WHILE RESEARCHING THE ENSLAVED CRAFTSPERSONS WHO CONSTRUCTED PRESERVATION VIRGINIA HISTORIC SITES [PRESERVATION VIRGINIA'S LEAD RESTORATION CRAFTSPERSON MIKE ADAMS IS APPROACHING RETIREMENT, AND TIME IS OF THE ESSENCE TO TRAIN THE NEXT GENERATION OF CRAFTSPERSONS. ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY BROUGHT ON BY THE PANDEMIC PUT THESE PLANS ON HOLD. AFTER 40 YEARS WITH PRESERVATION VIRGINIA, ADAMS HAS AMASSED AN AMAZING SKILL SET FOR PRESERVING HISTORIC BUILDINGS. IN HIRING, PRESERVATION VIRGINIA WILL BE INTENTIONAL AND DIRECT IN REACHING OUT TO HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES AS WELL AS AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY PROGRAMS TO HELP MAKE THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROFESSION MORE DIVERSE, EQUITABLE, ACCESSIBLE AND INCLUSIVE. DISCOVERIES GLEANED FROM PRESERVATION PROJECTS WILL BE PAIRED WITH PRIMARY SOURCE RESEARCH TO HELP IDENTIFY THE ENSLAVED MEN, WOMEN AND CHILDREN WHO ORIGINALLY BUILT THE FIVE HISTORIC PROPERTIES IN PRESERVATION VIRGINIA'S STEWARDSHIP. THESE FINDINGS, AS WELL AS THE CURRICULUM FOLLOWED BY THE NEW CRAFTSPERSONS, WILL BE DOCUMENTED THROUGH A VIDEO AND WEBINAR SERIES.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RESUME EXISTING PROGRAMS AND NEW RESEARCH DESIGNED TO IDENTIFY AND SHARE DISCOVERIES ABOUT THE ENSLAVED MEN, WOMEN, AND CHILDREN WHO ORIGINALLY BUILT THE FIVE HISTORIC PROPERTIES IN PRESERVATION VIRGINIA?S STEWARDSHIP  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PRESERVATION VIRGINIA WILL CONTINUE PRESERVATION WORK AT THE FIVE LOCATIONS IN THEIR CARE AND RESEARCH ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION METHODS USED BY ENSLAVED LABORERS, AND DOCUMENT DISCOVERIES THROUGH ?HOW-TO? VIDEOS AND WEBINARS. PRESERVATION VIRGINIA WILL PRODUCE 12 VIDEOS TO BE ADDED TO VP?S ONLINE DATABASE VOICES REMEMBERED. PRESERVATION VIRGINIA WILL RECRUIT TWO NEW STUDENT APPRENTICES FROM HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES TO TRAIN AS PRESERVATIONISTS AND ASSIST WITH RESEARCH.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PREPARE THE NEXT GENERATION OF CRAFTSPERSONS AND DOCUMENT AND SHARE NEW HISTORY ABOUT THE HISTORIC PROPERTIES IN PRESERVATION VIRGINIA?S STEWARDSHIP. MOREOVER, THE INTENTIONAL RECRUITMENT OF STUDENTS AT HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES PROVIDES STUDENTS WITH PAID OPPORTUNITIES AND ADVANCES DIVERSITY AND INCLUSION IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION. PRESERVATION VIRGINIA WILL RETAIN FOUR KEY PERSONNEL TO CONTINUE PRESERVATION WORK AND COMPLETE THE PROJECT.   INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: VISITORS, PUBLIC AUDIENCES, SCHOLARS, STAFF WORKERS, AND STUDENTS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PRESERVATION WORK AND NEW HISTORY THAT PRESERVATION VIRGINIA WILL WORK TO UNCOVER.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

HIRING TWO POSITIONS: MUSEUM CURATOR AND DIRECTOR OF LEARNING ENGAGEMENT [THE FRIENDS OF LOLANI PALACE SEEKS NEH SUPPORT OF $199,650 TO HIRE TWO OF SEVENTEEN POSITIONS ELIMINATED DURING THE COVID-19 CLOSURE OF THE MUSEUM, TO FILL THE CURATOR AND EDUCATOR POSITIONS. THIS FUNDING REQUEST ADDRESSES THE NEED TO ASSEMBLE A COLLABORATIVE TEAM OF EXPERTS, KNOWLEDGE-BEARERS, TEACHERS, AND MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS TO BUILD THE VOICE AND CONTENT TO SHOWCASE THE RICH HAWAIIAN HISTORY, CULTURE AND CONTEMPORARY ISSUES REFLECTED AT IOLANI PALACE. THESE TWO POSITIONS WILL IMPACT AN ESTIMATED 100,000 VISITORS PER YEAR AND OVER 5,000 CULTURAL TREASURES IN THE COLLECTIONS.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MAINTAIN AND DEVELOP PROGRAMS TO INTERPRET THE HISTORY OF IOLANI PALACE, A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK, AND PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL AND RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH ITS 5,000+ COLLECTIONS  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE FRIENDS OF THE IOLANI PALACE WILL EVALUATE EXISTING PROGRAMS AND RECOMMEND NEW CULTURAL PROGRAMS TO ASSIST WITH INTERPRETATION OF THE PALACE, ARCHIVES, AND COLLECTIONS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE PROGRAMS OF IOLANI PALACE PRESERVE, INTERPRET, AND SHARE HAWAII'S CULTURAL HISTORY AND INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL CONTRIBUTIONS OF HAWAIIAN PEOPLE. NEW PROGRAMS WILL HELP THE MUSEUM BECOME SUSTAINABLE WITH LESS EMPHASIS ON REVENUES FROM TOURISM. IOLANI WILL CREATE TWO NEW POSITIONS TO HELP MANAGE EXISTING PROGRAMS AND DEVELOP NEW ONES.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: VISITORS OF IOLANI PALACE WILL BENEFIT FROM THE EDUCATIONAL AND CULTURAL PROGRAMS OFFERED BY IOLANI PALACE.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

OKLAHOMA HISTORICAL SOCIETY AFRICAN AMERICAN COLLECTIONS DIGITIZATION PROJECT [HIRE A FULL-TIME PROJECT COORDINATOR AND A PART-TIME IMAGING SPECIALIST TO IDENTIFY, PRIORITIZE AND DIGITIZE THE OKLAHOMA HISTORICAL SOCIETY'S AFRICAN AMERICAN ARCHIVE COLLECTIONS. THE DIGITIZED MATERIALS WILL BE MADE AVAILABE FREE TO THE PUBLIC ON THE OKLAHOMA HISTORICAL SOCIETY'S DIGITAL PORTAL WEBSITE, THE GATEWAY TO OKLAHOMA HISTORY.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT TO THE OKLAHOMA HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL BE USED TO DIGITIZE ITS AFRICAN AMERICAN COLLECTIONS. IT WILL RETAIN TWO JOBS.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;A FULL-TIME PROJECT COORDINATOR AND A PART-TIME IMAGING SPECIALIST WILL BE HIRED TO IDENTIFY THE AFRICAN AMERICAN COLLECTIONS IN OHS ARCHIVES. THE MOST SIGNIFICANT COLLECTIONS AMONG THEM WILL BE DIGITIZED. DIGITIZED COLLECTIONS WILL BE MADE EASIER TO ACCESS, LOAN AND REPRODUCE. THESE COLLECTIONS WILL BE HOSTED FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC THROUGH THE OHS DIGITAL PORTAL, THE GATEWAY TO OKLAHOMA HISTORY. CURRENTLY, MORE THAN 20 AFRICAN AMERICAN COLLECTIONS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED. THEY CONSIST OF APPROXIMATELY 62 CUBIC FEET OF MANUSCRIPT MATERIALS THAT NEEDS TO BE TO BE PRIORITIZED FOR DIGITIZATION. PRIORITY WILL BE GIVEN TO THE MOST HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT MATERIALS, SUCH AS THE TULSA RACE RIOT (MASSACRE) COLLECTION, EX-SLAVE NARRATIVES, AND OKLAHOMA CIVIL RIGHTS LEADERS COLLECTIONS. DIGITIZATION WILL BE COMPLETED AND MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC WITHIN ONE YEAR.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL GROW IN TIME AND PROPEL NEW PROGRAMS, COLLECTIONS AND PARTNERSHIPS. EXPANSION OF OHS?S PUBLIC OFFERINGS WILL HELP IT CONTINUE TO BE A VIABLE OKLAHOMA HUMANITIES INSTITUTION IN THE FUTURE. IT WILL ENRICH THE ALREADY AVAILABLE DIGITAL COLLECTIONS AND ALLOW ARCHIVISTS, LIBRARIANS, RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS TO EXPLORE OKLAHOMA?S IMPORTANT HISTORIC AFRICAN AMERICAN COLLECTION. IT WILL ALSO ASSIST THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM, WHICH HAS BEGUN PROMOTING AFRICAN AMERICAN CULTURAL TOURISM WITHIN THE STATE.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE GRANT ARE THE GENERAL PUBLIC, HUMANITIES EXPERTS, PUBLIC HUMANITIES SPECIALISTS, AND MUSEUM STAFF.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

COLLECTIONS ACCESS AND ARTIFACT-CENTERED HUMANITIES EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING [THE MICHILIMACKINAC HISTORICAL SOCIETY IS REQUESTING FUNDING FROM THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE HUMANITIES TO EXPAND DIGITAL ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION, DEVELOP AND DELIVER EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING CONNECTED TO THE MICHILIMACKINAC AREA, AND TAKE STEPS TO PRESERVE AND PROTECT ITS COLLECTION.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE GRANT WILL HELP CREATE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND DIGITAL ACCESS TO MICHILIMACKINAC HISTORICAL SOCIETY?S MUSEUM, WHICH TRACES THE HISTORY OF THE STRAITS OF MACKINAC IN MICHIGAN. THE AWARD WILL ENABLE THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY TO RETAIN THREE JOBS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THE MUSEUM WILL UPGRADE THE SUBSCRIPTION OF ITS DATABASE TITLED PAST PERFECT, MOVE ITS DIGITAL COLLECTIONS TO A CLOUD-BASED PLATFORM, AND EXPAND ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION OF ARTIFACTS RELATED TO THE REGION?S INDIGENOUS TRIBES AND BRITISH, FRENCH, AND AMERICAN SETTLEMENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL DIGITIZE ITS COLLECTIONS USING HIGH RESOLUTION SCANNERS AND CAMERAS, IMPROVE ITS CATALOG ENTRIES REGARDING ITS COLLECTIONS, CATEGORIZE AND INTERPRET THESE ITEMS WITHIN THE DATABASE TO IMPROVE ACCESS AND FUTURE USE, AND IMPROVE CITATIONS WITHIN EACH RECORD. THE MUSEUM WILL CURATE ONLINE EXHIBITS, WHICH WILL BE ACCESSIBLE TO INDIVIDUALS, SCHOOL GROUPS, RESEARCHERS, AND ENTHUSIASTS FREE OF CHARGE. THE MUSEUM WILL HAVE A SERIES OF LOCAL HISTORY PRESENTATIONS TO HIGHLIGHT ITS COLLECTION AND ITS SIGNIFICANCE FOR THE REGION. THE MUSEUM WILL STREAM THESE PRESENTATIONS AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE ON ITS WEBSITE, FACEBOOK, AND YOUTUBE ACCOUNTS. THE MUSEUM STAFF WILL COMPLETE THE PROCESS OF DIGITIZATION, RESEARCHING, PRESERVING, AND CATALOGING OF THE COLLECTION, AND DEVELOP A ?BEHIND THE SCENES? VIDEO SERIES HIGHLIGHTING DIFFERENT PIECES TO COVER PRESERVATION/CONSERVATION TECHNIQUES, INTERESTING HISTORIES OR ITEMS, AND LOCAL CONNECTIONS TO FAMILY AND COMMUNITY HERITAGE.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;OUTCOMES INCLUDE EXPANDING AND UPGRADING TECHNOLOGICAL CAPACITY AND LAUNCHING NEW INITIATIVES TO EXPAND THE MICHILIMACKINAC HISTORICAL SOCIETY?S OUTREACH AND IMPACT.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE GRANT ARE THE GENERAL PUBLIC, HUMANITIES EXPERTS, PUBLIC HUMANITIES SPECIALISTS, AND MEMBERS OF THE THE MICHILIMACKINAC HISTORICAL SOCIETY STAFF.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

DEMOCRATIZING HISTORY: DIGITIZATION FOR A NEW WISCONSIN HISTORY MUSEUM [THE WISCONSIN HISTORICAL SOCIETY IS WEATHERING THE IMPACTS OF THE CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIC AT A PIVOTAL TIME IN ITS HISTORY. THE SOCIETY IS IN THE MIDST OF A MULTI-YEAR CAMPAIGN TO BUILD A NEW HISTORY MUSEUM, WHICH WILL RELY HEAVILY ON DIGITIZED COLLECTIONS AND REQUIRE ROBUST CAPACITY IN THE SOCIETY'S DIGITAL COLLECTIONS AND IT TEAMS. PRE-PANDEMIC, THE SOCIETY LAUNCHED AN INITIATIVE TO SCALE UP OPERATIONAL READINESS FOR DIGITIZATION. HOWEVER, AS A RESULT OF PANDEMIC-RELATED REVENUE LOSSES, THE SOCIETY HAD TO REASSIGN STAFF DEDICATED TO DIGITAL COLLECTIONS ACCESS WORK TO STATE AGENCIES CHARGED WITH COVID EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLANNING, SETTING THE PROJECT A YEAR BEHIND. GRANT FUNDS WOULD ENABLE THE SOCIETY TO 1) HIRE NECESSARY STAFF AND PROVIDE TRAINING TO SUPPORT EXPANDED DIGITIZATION SERVICES, 2) CONDUCT AN ASSESSMENT OF CURRENT DIGITIZATION SERVICES AND DIGITAL STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES, AND 3) REPLACE EQUIPMENT TO GET DIGITIZATION WORK BACK ON SCHEDULE FOR THE OPENING OF THE NEW MUSEUM.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND NINE STAFF POSITIONS AND MODERNIZE THE DIGITIZATION SERVICES AT A STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY IN MADISON, WISCONSIN.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE WISCONSIN HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL INITIATE THE FIRST YEAR OF A FIVE-YEAR PROJECT TO MODERNIZE THEIR COLLECTION DIGITIZATION SERVICES UNDER THIS GRANT. THE SOCIETY WILL HIRE AND TRAIN STAFF TO SUPPORT THE EXPANSION OF DIGITIZATION SERVICES, CONDUCT AN ASSESSMENT OF ITS CURRENT DIGITIZATION SERVICES AND DIGITAL STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES, AND REPLACE NECESSARY EQUIPMENT.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FUNDING WILL RETAIN SIX STAFF POSITIONS, CREATE THREE NEW POSITIONS, AND REINSTATE CRITICAL COLLECTION DIGITIZATION ACTIVITIES THAT WERE HALTED DUE TO THE PANDEMIC.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GRANT ACTIVITIES WILL BENEFIT THE STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY OF WISCONSIN AND THEIR BROAD AUDIENCE, WHICH INCLUDES SCHOLARS, STUDENTS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITHIN THE STATE AND BEYOND.  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE PROJECT DOES NOT INTEND TO ISSUE SUBAWARDS.]

STEWARDING AND PROVIDING DIGITAL ACCESS TO THE ROSENBACH'S RARE BOOKS AND MANUSCRIPTS COLLECTION [THE ROSENBACH REQUESTS FUNDING TO PLAN AND MOVE FORWARD A SERIES OF COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS COMPRISING CATALOGING THE MAJORITY OF THE RARE BOOK AND MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION, MIGRATION TO A CLOUD-BASED COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (CMS), A COLLECTION MANAGEMENT POLICY UPDATE, THE SALE OF SEVERAL HUNDRED OF NON-ACCESSIONED ITEMS, AND COLLECTIONS POLICY-DRIVEN DEACCESSIONING. THE ROSENBACH CURRENTLY LACKS THE CAPACITY TO MANAGE THESE PROJECTS AND REQUESTS FUNDING FOR TWO ADDITIONAL FTE POSITIONS TO EFFICIENTLY MOVE THEM FORWARD, ALONG WITH SOME EQUIPMENT/SOFTWARE PURCHASES TOWARD THE SAME END. THESE PROJECTS ARE PART OF THE ROSENBACH?S STRATEGIC PLAN (FY17-FY22) AND HAVE BEEN DEFERRED BECAUSE OF THE PANDEMIC.] [PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT A PHILADELPHIA MUSEUM AND LIBRARY IN RETAINING THREE STAFF POSITIONS, CREATING TWO NEW&NBSP;POSITIONS, AND DEVELOPING THEIR ONLINE CATALOGUE. &NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE ROSENBACH LIBRARY WILL IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS INVOLVING THE CATALOGING OF MOST OF ITS RARE BOOK AND MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION, MIGRATING LIBRARY RECORDS TO A CLOUD-BASED COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, AND UPDATING ITS COLLECTION MANAGEMENT POLICY. THE ORGANIZATION WILL HIRE TWO NEW STAFF MEMBERS TO SUPPORT THESE ACTIVITIES.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FUNDING WILL RETAIN THE FOUR EXISTING LIBRARY STAFF, CREATE TWO NEW POSITIONS, AND ALLOW THE ORGANIZATION TO DEVELOP THEIR ONLINE CATALOGUE. &NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE LIBRARY?S COLLECTIONS ARE OF PARTICULAR INTEREST TO SCHOLARS AND STUDENTS OF AMERICAN AND BRITISH LITERATURE AND HISTORY, BUT THE PROJECT WILL ALSO MAKE THE LIBRARY?S COLLECTIONS MORE ACCESSIBLE TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. &NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE PROJECT DOES NOT INTEND TO ISSUE SUBAWARDS.]

ASHEVILLE ART MUSEUM COLLECTION ACCESS, INTERPRETATION, AND EVALUATION [THE ASHEVILLE ART MUSEUM WILL UNDERTAKE A THREE-PRONGED PROJECT TO IMPROVE COLLECTION ACCESS, INTERPRETATION, AND EVALUATION. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PHOTOGRAPH AND CATALOGUE APPROXIMATELY 800 COLLECTION OBJECTS FOCUSING PRIMARILY ON THREE-DIMENSIONAL OBJECTS THAT HAVE SPECIAL SIGNIFICANCE TO THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION. ADDITIONALLY, THE MUSEUM WILL CONVENE A TEAM OF SCHOLARS TO ENGAGE WITH THESE WORKS AND CREATE INTERPRETIVE CONTENT FOR DIGITAL AND PHYSICAL EXHIBITIONS, THE MUSEUM'S MULTIMEDIA TOUR, AND OTHER PUBLIC RESOURCES. FINALLY, THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE AN EXHIBITION EVALUATOR TO ASSESS THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION INSTALLATION INTERSECTIONS IN AMERICAN ART. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ADVANCE THE MUSEUM'S MISSION BY SERVING OUR COMMUNITY WITH ACCESS TO UNIQUE WORKS OF ART, SHARING STORIES THAT DEEPEN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF OURSELVES AND OUR COMMUNITIES, AND PRESERVING KNOWLEDGE OF OBJECTS AND ARCHIVES THAT ARE INHERENT TO OUR CULTURAL HERITAGE AND UNDERSTANDING.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO&NBSP;RETAIN FIVE TO SEVEN STAFF MEMBERS, EMPLOY SEVERAL CONTRACTORS AND TO PAY STIPENDS FOR TEN HUMANITIES SCHOLARS.&NBSP;&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: &NBSP;THE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE&NBSP;PHOTOGRAPHING AND CATALOGING OBJECTS FROM THE COLLECTION, AS WELL AS CREATING INTERPRETIVE CONTENT FOR DIGITAL AND PHYSICAL EXHIBITIONS IN CONSULTATION WITH A TEAM OF SCHOLARS.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ENHANCED ACCESS TO AND RICHER INTERPRETATION OF 800 OBJECTS FROM THE COLLECTION WHICH INCLUDES TWENTIETH- AND TWENTY-FIRST-CENTURY AMERICAN ART THAT FOCUSES ON THE DIVERSITY OF THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE INCREASED ACCESS TO DIGITAL AND PHYSICAL EXHIBITIONS WOULD&NBSP;BENEFIT THE GENERAL PUBLIC OF WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA AND OTHERS WHO ARE INTERESTED IN THE ART OF SOUTHERN APPALACHIA.&NBSP;&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

NEW ORLEANS MUSEUM OF ART PRESERVATION AND ACCESS PERSONNEL SUPPORT [NOMA TYPICALLY HOSTS UP TO 20 EXHIBITIONS ANNUALLY SUPPLEMENTED BY A RICH AND VARIED ARRAY OF PUBLIC PROGRAMMING INITIATIVES TAILORED TO ENGAGE VISITORS IN DIRECT DIALOGUE AND INTERACTION WITH THE HISTORICAL, ANTHROPOLOGICAL, AND PHILOSOPHICAL ASPECTS OF THE WORKS AND/OR PERFORMANCES. THE CURRENT PROJECT SUPPORTS THE PERSONNEL NECESSARY TO MEET TWO OF NOMA?S MOST PRESSING NEEDS THAT HAVE EMERGED IN THE LAST YEAR, AS A DIRECT RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. NOMA SEEKS FUNDING TO SUPPORT PRESERVATION AND ACCESS PERSONNEL, INCLUDING INTERDEPARTMENTAL PROJECT MANAGER AND DIGITAL ARCHIVIST, FOR A PERIOD OF 1-YEAR BEGINNING IN OCTOBER OF 2021.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS&NBSP;TO&NBSP;HIRE&NBSP;TWO FULL-TIME POSITIONS?AN&NBSP;INTERDEPARTMENTAL&NBSP;PROJECT&NBSP;MANAGER AND?A?DIGITAL&NBSP;ARCHIVIST?TO OVERSEE THE MUSEUM?S CROSS-DEPARTMENTAL&NBSP;EXHIBIT DEVELOPMENT&NBSP;AND?ENSURE THAT DIGITALLY CURATED MATERIAL IS PRESERVED FOR LONG-TERM USE.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THE&NBSP;INTERDEPARTMENTAL&NBSP;PROJECT&NBSP;MANAGER WILL FACILITATE THE MUSEUM?S ONLINE EXHIBIT PROGRAMMING FROM CONCEPTION TO COMPLETION WHILE ENSURING THAT THE ENTIRE PROCESS CONTINUES TO INCORPORATE HUMANITIES-FOCUSED SCHOLARSHIP, COMMUNITY-INFORMED PERSPECTIVES, AND IN-DEPTH EXPLORATION OF ART AND ARTISTS.&NBSP; THE&NBSP;DIGITAL&NBSP;ARCHIVIST WILL OVERSEE THE PRESERVATION OF DIGITALLY CURATED MATERIAL PRODUCED DURING THESE PLANNING AND PRODUCTION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING EXHIBITION AND MOBILE GUIDES.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;&NBSP;FOR THE UPCOMING SEASON, THE MUSEUM PLANS TO PRODUCE 20 EXHIBITIONS AND SUPPLEMENTAL PUBLIC PROGRAMMING INITIATIVES TAILORED TO ENGAGE VISITORS IN DIRECT DIALOGUE AND INTERACTION WITH THE HISTORICAL, ANTHROPOLOGICAL, AND PHILOSOPHICAL ASPECTS OF THE ART WORKS AND PERFORMANCES.&NBSP;&NBSP;PROGRAMS&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;EXPLORE, FOR EXAMPLE,?ROMAN CATHOLIC ART FROM PORTUGUESE INDIA,?JAPANESE ART FROM THE EDO PERIOD,?BLACK STUDIO PHOTOGRAPHY, AND?NEW ORLEANS ARTIST DAWN?DEDEAUX.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE ONLINE EXHIBITION PROGRAMMING&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;BENEFIT THE MUSEUM?S PRIMARY AUDIENCE OF 1.27 MILLION RESIDENTS IN THE GREATER NEW ORLEANS METRO AREA, INCLUDING ORLEANS AND ADJACENT PARISHES; DOZENS OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND ORGANIZATIONS WHO REGULARLY ENGAGE WITH WORKING ARTISTS, WRITERS, HISTORIANS, AND HUMANITIES EDUCATORS THROUGH ACTIVITIES SUCH AS TALKS, LECTURES, CLASSES, AND WORKSHOPS; AND RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC BEYOND LOUISIANA PARTAKING IN THE VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

REGIONAL ARCHIVES FOR CALIFORNIA'S CENTRAL VALLEY [AS A CORNERSTONE COLLECTION FOR ESTABLISHING A REGIONAL ARCHIVES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, MERCED, THE CALIFORNIA AGRICULTURAL RESOURCES ARCHIVE PRESERVES AND PROVIDES ACCESS TO SIGNIFICANT DOCUMENTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIAL SPANNING THE 100-YEAR HISTORY OF COOPERATIVE EXTENSION IN CALIFORNIA. THESE COLLECTIONS DOCUMENT THE DEVELOPMENT OF RURAL COMMUNITIES AND THE EVOLUTION OF THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE IN ONE OF THE MOST PRODUCTIVE AGRICULTURAL REGIONS ON THE GLOBE. AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN FUNDS WILL SUSTAIN ESSENTIAL STAFF TO STEWARD AND SUPPORT ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS?SPECIFICALLY FROM COUNTIES RECENTLY IMPACTED BY SEVERE WILDFIRE?AND TO CONDUCT OUTREACH AND INSTRUCTIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT WILL ENGAGE FACULTY, STUDENTS, LOCAL EDUCATORS, AND THE BROADER PUBLIC. THESE ACTIVITIES ARE INTEGRAL TO ADVANCING HUMANISTIC SCHOLARSHIP AND PUBLIC HUMANITIES IN A HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED REGION THAT REMAINS THE SLOWEST IN THE STATE TO RECOVER FROM COVID-19.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN FOUR POSITIONS INCLUDING AN ARCHIVIST, ONE GRADUATE ASSISTANT, AND TWO UNDERGRADUATE ASSISTANTS TO PRESERVE AND MAKE ACCESSIBLE COLLECTIONS FROM THE CALIFORNIA AGRICULTURAL RESOURCES ARCHIVE, WHICH DOCUMENTS THE RURAL COUNTIES LOCATED AT THE NORTH END OF CALIFORNIA?S CENTRAL VALLEY.&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THE PROJECT STAFF WILL ASSESS, INVENTORY, AND PRESERVE TWO COLLECTIONS THAT CONTAIN HISTORIC&NBSP;AGRICULTURAL&NBSP;RECORDS OF SUTTER, YUBA, AND BUTTE COUNTIES.&NBSP;IN ADDITION TO PROCESSING THESE COLLECTIONS, THE ARCHIVIST WILL MEET WITH FACULTY TO PLAN AND PREPARE IN-COURSE UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE INSTRUCTION, DEVELOP TOURS AND PRESENTATIONS, AND ANSWER REFERENCE REQUESTS.&NBSP;&NBSP;&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE COLLECTIONS PROPOSED FOR ARCHIVAL PROCESSING WILL INCLUDE DOCUMENTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIAL THAT PROVIDE PRIMARY DOCUMENTATION OF LOCAL LAND DEVELOPMENT, CROP RESEARCH AND CHANGING AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, RURAL DOMESTIC LIFE, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT THROUGH&NBSP;FARM&NBSP;BUREAUS AND OTHER ASSOCIATIONS.&NBSP;IN ADDITION, PROJECT STAFF WILL ADD AN ESTIMATED 4,000 PHOTOGRAPHS, HOST SUMMER WORKSHOPS FOR STUDENTS, AND DEVELOP AT LEAST ONE PHYSICAL AND ONE DIGITAL EXHIBIT FEATURING COLLECTION MATERIALS.&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE RECORDS OF THE CALIFORNIA AGRICULTURAL RESOURCES ARCHIVE WILL BENEFIT THE RURAL COMMUNITIES OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY WHICH FACE CHALLENGES OF DROUGHT, WILDFIRES, CLIMATE CHANGE, URBANIZATION, AND POPULATION GROWTH;&NBSP;LOCAL YOUTH PARTICIPATING IN HISTORY PROGRAMS DEVELOPED BY THE ORGANIZATION 4-H; RESEARCHERS; STUDENTS; AND THE PUBLIC.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

COLORADO CHICANO MOVEMENT ARCHIVES: TELLING THE STORY OF THE CHICANO QUEST FOR JUSTICE [THE COLORADO CHICANO MOVEMENT ARCHIVES PRESERVES THE HISTORY OF AN IMPORTANT BUT LESSER KNOWN CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT. THIS GRANT SEEKS FUNDING FOR THE ARCHIVIST POSITION FOR THE 21-22 ACADEMIC YEAR TO PROVIDE A BRIDGE TO KEEP THE ARCHIVES OPEN UNTIL UNIVERSITY FUNDING CAN BE RESTORED IN THE 22-23 ACADEMIC YEAR. THE ARCHIVIST WILL RESUME WORK ON RECENTLY DIGITIZED COLLECTIONS TO MAKE THEM ACCESSIBLE. WITH FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT, THE ARCHIVES WILL CREATE TWO MOBILE ARCHIVIST KITS AND HIRE A CONSULTANT TO TRAIN CHICANO COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO ASSIST IN COLLECTING HISTORICAL MATERIALS. FINALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR ENHANCED EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS TO INCREASE THE IMPACT OF THE COLLECTIONS BY PROVIDING EXPERIENTIAL EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS AND SPONSORING A SERIES OF LECTURES AND PANEL DISCUSSIONS OPEN TO FACULTY, STAFF, STUDENTS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO HIRE AN ARCHIVIST TO INVENTORY, PROCESS, AND ENHANCE DIGITAL ACCESS FOR THE UNIVERSITY?S CHICANO MOVEMENT&NBSP;HUMANITIES COLLECTIONS, AS WELL AS TRAIN COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN CONDUCTING ORAL HISTORIES THAT DOCUMENT LOCAL HISTORY.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE HIRED ARCHIVIST WILL CREATE METADATA FOR 300 DIGITIZED PHOTOGRAPHS, DIGITIZE 200 FILMS, AND CREATE FINDING AIDS FOR THE COLORADO CHICANO MOVEMENT ARCHIVES.&NBSP; IN ADDITION, THE ARCHIVIST WILL WORK WITH A CONSULTANT TO ASSEMBLE MOBILE ARCHIVIST KITS TO TRAIN COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN GATHERING AND PRESERVING HERITAGE ITEMS&NBSP;AND CONDUCTING ORAL HISTORIES.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE WORK TO&NBSP;DIGITIZE&NBSP;500 ITEMS IN THE SPECIAL COLLECTIONS WILL PRESERVE AND MAKE ACCESSIBLE RARE PHOTOS, JOURNALS, AND LOGBOOKS DOCUMENTING THE CHICANO MOVEMENT AND UNITED FARM WORKERS&NBSP;ALONG WITH OTHER SOCIAL AND CULTURAL ACTIVITIES.&NBSP;&NBSP;THE ARCHIVIST WILL TRAIN FOUR STUDENT INTERNS&NBSP;ON HOW&NBSP;TO CONDUCT A VARIETY OF ARCHIVAL WORK INCLUDING PROCESSING AND DIGITIZING COLLECTIONS, CREATING METADATA, AND TRANSCRIBING ORAL HISTORIES.&NBSP; FINALLY, COMMUNITY MEMBERS TRAINED IN ARCHIVAL AND ORAL HISTORY PRACTICES WILL BE ABLE TO COLLECT AT LEAST 10 INTERVIEWS AND ITEMS THAT CHRONICLE THE COMMUNITY?S HISTORY.&NBSP;&NBSP;ALL OF&NBSP;THIS WORK WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN IN-PERSON AND ONLINE DISCUSSION SERIES ON TOPICS RELATED TO THE CHICANO MOVEMENT.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE PRESERVATION WORK AND TRAINING WILL&NBSP;BENEFIT&NBSP;STUDENTS AND FACULTY OF THIS&NBSP;HISPANIC-SERVING INSTITUTION;&NBSP;COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITHIN SOUTHERN COLORADO, A PART OF THE STATE CHARACTERIZED BY A LARGELY LOW-INCOME POPULATION; AND RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC INTERESTED IN LEARNING ABOUT THE COLORADO CHICANO MOVEMENT.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

MULVANE ART MUSEUM ARP [THE MULVANE ART MUSEUM AT WASHBURN UNIVERSITY OF TOPEKA, KS, SEEKS FUNDING TO SUSTAIN CORE HUMANITIES PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES THROUGH ONSITE AND ONLINE ACCESS. THE PROJECT ENABLES THE MULVANE TO HIRE OTHERWISE UNAVAILABLE PROFESSIONAL STAFF: THE PROJECT FUNDS ONE FROZEN POSITION (FROZEN DUE TO COVID); HIRE A ONE-YEAR APPOINTMENT DEDICATED TO BUILD AND STRENGTHEN SUSTAINABLE HUMANITIES-FOCUSED ACADEMIC PROGRAMS ACROSS THE CAMPUS; AND ENGAGE A PART-TIME SUPPORT POSITION TO EXPAND OUTREACH AND PROGRAMS TO BUILD AUDIENCES; AND, SUPPORT DIVERSE FINE ARTS PROGRAMS AND SPEAKERS FOR STUDENTS IN ART, MUSIC, AND THEATER THROUGH COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN THE MULVANE AND WASHBURN DEPARTMENTS OF ART, MUSIC, AND THEATER. ADDITIONAL SUPPORT IS REQUESTED FOR A SCANNER SUITABLE FOR SCANNING ARTWORK AND COMPUTER EQUIPMENT/SOFTWARE FOR STAFF IN ORDER TO EXPAND ONLINE COLLECTION ACCESS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO REHIRE A COLLECTIONS MANAGER, TO HIRE A CURATOR, AND TO HIRE A CONTENT DEVELOPER TO COMPLETE THE CATALOGING AND DIGITIZING OF THE PERMANENT COLLECTION.&NBSP;&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE STAFF WOULD FINISH PROCESSING OBJECTS AND ADD THEM TO THE MUSEUM'S DIGITAL IMAGE DATABASE. THE CURATOR WOULD DEVELOP EXHIBITS USING THE PERMANENT COLLECTION AS A RESOURCE.&NBSP;COMMUNITY OUTREACH EFFORTS AND IN-PERSON PUBLIC PROGRAMS WOULD BE EXPANDED.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE&NBSP;EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE ENHANCED ONLINE COLLECTIONS, ENRICHED EXHIBITIONS, AND MORE FREQUENT PUBLIC PROGRAMS.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND THE COMMUNITY WOULD BENEFIT FROM THESE PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT HAS NO PLANS TO SUBAWARD.&NBSP;&NBSP;]

MANY HANDS [COVID-19 HAS RESULTED IN LOST EARNED INCOME AND HAS ALSO INCREASED EXPENSES. THE MANY HANDS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE MCRC'S EFFORTS TO MITIGATE THE SPREAD OF COVID-19. HANDS-UP TO THE OPPORTUNITY TO FUND PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT (PPE). THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO RETROFIT CURRENT FIXTURES WITH MOTION SENSORS TO HELP KEEP HANDS-OFF HIGH USE AREAS AND HELP PREVENT THE SPREAD OF COVID-19. FUNDING WILL ALSO INCREASE MAKAH KNOWLEDGE AND HISTORY THAT HAS BEEN HANDED-DOWN FROM OUR ANCESTORS THROUGH STORIES IN THE MCRC ARCHIVAL COLLECTION. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO AT LEAST 60 STORIES. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND AT LEAST 7 ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS THAT WILL PROVIDE HELPING-HANDS TO OTHERS BY SHARING OUR EXPERIENCES, TRIALS, TRIBULATIONS, AND TRIUMPHS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN FOUR MUSEUM AND ARCHIVES SPECIALISTS TO CONDUCT ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS AND INCREASE ACCESS TO TRIBAL COLLECTIONS OF THE MAKAH CULTURAL AND RESEARCH CENTER.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;STAFF PLAN TO&NBSP;CONDUCT ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS TO PRESERVE MAKAH STORIES AND ADD THESE ORAL HISTORIES TO ITS DIGITAL REPOSITORIES.&NBSP;&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;&NBSP;MAKAH CULTURAL HERITAGE WOULD BE PRESERVED THROUGH THE COLLECTION OF ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS.&NBSP;&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: BENEFICIARIES WOULD BE MEMBERS OF THE MAKAH INDIAN TRIBE AS WELL AS BROADER COMMUNITIES OF THE PUBLIC AND OF HUMANITIES SCHOLARS.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT HAS NO PLANS TO SUBAWARD.&NBSP;&NBSP;]

CADE LIBRARY LOUISIANA PICTORIAL HISTORY INITIATIVE (CLLPHI) [JOHN B. CADE LIBRARY PROPOSES THE CADE LIBRARY LOUISIANA PICTORIAL HISTORY INITIATIVE (CLLPHI) TO DIGITIZE, CATALOG, AND DISSEMINATE COLLECTIONS OF HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE TO THE UNIVERSITY COMMUNITY AS WELL AS USERS INTERESTED IN AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY. CCLPHI WILL PRESERVE AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO TWO HISTORICAL COLLECTIONS: THE LOUISIANA COLORED TEACHERS JOURNAL, AND THE BATON ROUGE CIVIL RIGHTS PROTEST PHOTOGRAPHY COLLECTION, A PICTORIAL COLLECTION OF LIFE IN BATON ROUGE IN THE 1960S AND 70S WHEN SEGREGATION AND INTEGRATION MET COLLIDING PATHS. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC ILLUMINATED THE NECESSITY TO PROVIDE DIGITAL ACCESS TO THESE COLLECTIONS. NEH FUNDING WILL BE USED FOR PERSONNEL SUPPORT, DIGITIZATION, AND PRESERVATION OF COLLECTIONS. IT IS IMPORTANT TO PRESERVE AND INCREASE ACCESS TO THESE CRITICAL COLLECTIONS THAT DOCUMENT THE STORIES OF AMERICA'S HISTORY.] [PURPOSE:'THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO&NBSP;RETAIN&NBSP;FOUR SENIOR POSITIONS AND THREE STAFF POSITIONS,'TO HIRE'A GRADUATE STUDENT AND A CONSULTANT,'AND'TO&NBSP;PURCHASE&NBSP;SUPPLIES'TO'ENABLE'THE'PRESERVATION,'DIGITIZATION, AND PROCESSING'OF'MATERIALS FROM'TWO COLLECTIONS'RELATED TO'TWENTIETH-CENTURY AFRICAN-AMERICAN HISTORY.''&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;SENIOR STAFF, INCLUDING'THE&NBSP;DEAN OF&NBSP;LIBRARIES,'HEAD OF&NBSP;ACCESS&NBSP;SERVICES,'THE&NBSP;UNIVERSITY&NBSP;ARCHIVIST,'AND OTHER STAFF, INCLUDING A&NBSP;GRADUATE AND ARCHIVE ASSISTANT,'A CATALOGUER,'AND&NBSP;A WEB SPECIALIST,&NBSP;AND A CONSULTANT CONSERVATOR'WOULD'PRESERVE AND'PROCESS'SELECTED COLLECTIONS AT THE JOHN&NBSP;B. CADE LIBRARY'WHICH MAINTAINS&NBSP;NUMEROUS'PHOTOGRAPHS'PERTAINING TO'THE AFRICAN-AMERICAN EXPERIENCE IN LOUISIANA.&NBSP;&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:'THIS&NBSP;PROJECT WILL DIGITIZE, CATALOG, AND DISSEMINATE SEVERAL&NBSP;IMPORTANT&NBSP;ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS,&NBSP;INCLUDING&NBSP;THE LOUISIANA COLORED TEACHERS' JOURNAL'OF'THE LOUISIANA COLORED&NBSP;TEACHERS ASSOCIATION AND THE BATON ROUGE CIVIL RIGHTS PROTEST PHOTOGRAPHY COLLECTION'CONTAINING OVER 17,000 IMAGES DOCUMENTING THE&NBSP;CIVIL&NBSP;RIGHTS&NBSP;MOVEMENT.&NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THESE COLLECTIONS HAVE&NBSP;HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE TO THE UNIVERSITY COMMUNITY AS WELL AS USERS INTERESTED IN AFRICAN-AMERICAN HISTORY IN THE STATE OF LOUISIANA.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:'THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

CONTINUED ACCESS TO HUMANITIES RELATED COLLECTIONS AND PROGRAMS IN CALENDAR YEAR 2022 AT THE CARNEGIE LIBRARY OF HOMESTEAD [THE HISTORIC CARNEGIE LIBRARY OF HOMESTEAD (CLOH) IS APPLYING TO THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT OF THE HUMANITIES? AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN GRANT FOR $200,000. THESE FUNDS WILL GO TOWARDS THE SALARY AND FRINGE BENEFITS OF SENIOR STAFF WHO OVERSEE THE LIBRARY?S HUMANITIES-RELATED COLLECTIONS AND PROGRAMMING. ADDITIONAL FUNDS WILL BE USED TO DIGITIZE MICROFILM OF LOCAL NEWSPAPERS, THE ONLY RECORDS IN MANY CASES, THAT WERE INACCESSIBLE WHILE THE LIBRARY FACILITIES WERE CLOSED TO THE PUBLIC IN 2020.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN SIX STAFF POSITIONS&NBSP;INCLUDING THE LIBRARY DIRECTOR,&NBSP;PROGRAM&NBSP;COORDINATOR, AND?TWO?LIBRARY CLERKS, WHO WILL PRESERVE LOCAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS AND DEVELOP HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING THROUGHOUT THE YEAR.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DIGITIZING HISTORIC LOCAL NEWSPAPER MICROFILM AND HOLDING COMMUNITY HUMANITIES PROGRAMS SUCH AS EVENTS CELEBRATING NATIONAL POETRY MONTH AND WEEKLY BOOK CLUBS FOR ADULTS AND TEENS.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE DIGITIZATION&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;MAKE ACCESSIBLE&NBSP;232 ROLLS OF HISTORIC LOCAL NEWSPAPERS FROM WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA.&NBSP; IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL&NBSP;EXPAND&NBSP;THE LIBRARY?S&NBSP;SUBSCRIPTIONS TO HUMANITIES ONLINE RESOURCES&NBSP;AND SUSTAIN&NBSP;ACCESS TO ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS DOCUMENTING LOCAL ETHNIC HISTORY.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE&NBSP;RETENTION OF KEY LIBRARY STAFF&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;ENHANCE&NBSP;ACCESS TO LIBRARY SERVICES AND RESOURCES&NBSP;THAT&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;BENEFIT RESIDENTS OF WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA MUNICIPALITIES FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF PITTSBURGH, INCLUDING HOMESCHOOLED CHILDREN PARTAKING IN HISTORY AND ART-RELATED PROGRAMMING HOSTED BY THE LIBRARY AND ATTENDEES TO ONE OF THE HUNDREDS OF HUMANITIES-RELATED ACTIVITIES HELD EVERY YEAR, AS WELL AS SCHOLARS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC&NBSP;INTERESTED IN CONDUCTING REGIONAL HISTORICAL RESEARCH.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

CORONAVIRUS EMERGENCY RELIEF TO RETAIN HUMANITIES STAFF [THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE EMERGENCY RELIEF TO THE APPLICANT TO ENABLE IT TO MAINTAIN AND HIRE HUMANITIES POSITIONS THAT ARE IN JEOPARDY AS A RESULT OF THE CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIC. THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES ARE SHORT-TERM PROJECTS THAT EMPHASIZE RETAINING AND HIRING HUMANITIES STAFF IN THE APPLICANT'S COLLECTIONS & CURATORIAL AFFAIRS DEPARTMENT TO MAKE ARCHIVAL RECORDS AND COLLECTIONS OBJECTS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN SIX STAFF MEMBERS FROM THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION AND CURATORIAL AFFAIRS DEPARTMENT AND HIRE AN ADDITIONAL CURATOR TO PRESERVE THE ARCHIVAL AND ART COLLECTIONS OF JAMES DEERING AND HIS ESTATE.&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;MUSEUM STAFF WILL&NBSP;PARTICIPATE IN THE ONGOING CATALOGING, DIGITIZING AND INTERPRETATION OF ARCHIVAL AND COLLECTIONS INFORMATION.&NBSP;THIS WILL INCLUDE CREATING&NBSP;FINDING AIDS OF EXISTING COLLECTIONS; DIGITIZING AND CREATING METADATA FOR&NBSP;HISTORIC&NBSP;CORRESPONDENCE&NBSP;AND FINANCIAL RECORDS; CLEANING AND PHOTOGRAPHING OBJECTS; AND PUBLISHING WEB CONTENT.&NBSP;&NBSP;&NBSP;&NBSP;&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE PROCESSING AND DIGITIZATION OF COLLECTION ITEMS WILL RESULT IN&NBSP;DIGITIZING&NBSP;2,400 PIECES OF CORRESPONDENCE AND FINANCIAL RECORDS,&NBSP;CREATING&NBSP;16 FINDING AIDS, PHOTOGRAPHING 260 COLLECTIONS OBJECTS,&NBSP;CONDUCTING&NBSP;CONSERVATION TREATMENT OF AT LEAST FOUR OBJECTS IN THE MAIN HOUSE COURTYARD OR DECORATED ROOM,&NBSP;DEVELOPING&NBSP;ONE PUBLIC PROGRAM, AND PUBLISHING&NBSP;AT LEAST 10 WEB OR VIDEO STORIES. ALTOGETHER THE COLLECTIONS WOULD FURTHER&NBSP;THE&NBSP;MUSEUM'S MISSION TO SUPPORT RESEARCH AND PUBLIC PROGRAMMING IN ART HISTORY, ARCHITECTURE, AND THE LABOR AND SOCIAL HISTORY OF MIAMI, FLORIDA.&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE ONGOING COLLECTIONS CARE AND ARCHIVAL DIGITIZATION EFFORTS WILL REACH THE MUSEUM'S DIVERSE AUDIENCES OF RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC REPRESENTED BY APPROXIMATELY 300,000 VISITORS ANNUALLY, 74,000 MONTHLY VISITORS TO THE WEBSITE, 45,000 EMAIL SUBSCRIBERS, AND MORE THAN 61,000 SOCIAL MEDIA FOLLOWERS.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

PROTECTING HUMANITIES STAFF AND DIGITAL ASSETS THROUGH DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM IMPLEMENTATION [THROUGH THIS PROPOSAL, THE MUSEUM WILL ADDRESS AN INSTITUTIONAL PRIORITY TO PLAN AND BEGIN IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MANAGEMENT AND PRESERVATION OF OUR NEARLY 400,000 DIGITAL HUMANITIES ASSETS, APPLYING TO DIGITAL ASSETS THE SAME LEVEL OF EXCELLENCE THAT IT HAS DEVELOPED FOR ITS PHYSICAL COLLECTIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST POST-PANDEMIC RECOVERY OF THE MUSEUM AND THE HUMANITIES SECTOR BY SUPPORTING THE RETENTION OF CURRENT HUMANITIES STAFF, HIRING A TERM HUMANITIES STAFF POSITION, ENGAGING A CONSULTING FIRM EXPERIENCED IN HUMANITIES DIGITAL MANAGEMENT, AND PURCHASING A DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (DAMS). BY PLANNING FOR PROPER MANAGEMENT AND PRESERVATION OF OUR DIGITAL ASSETS, DMNS MAKES THESE COLLECTIONS MORE ACCESSIBLE TO MUSEUM STAFF, SOURCE COMMUNITIES, RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN NINE EXISTING STAFF POSITIONS?INCLUDING&NBSP;THE DIRECTOR OF INTEGRATIVE COLLECTIONS,&NBSP;&NBSP;AN&NBSP;ARCHIVIST,&NBSP;REGISTRAR,&NBSP;CURATOR OF&NBSP;ARCHAEOLOGY, AND DIRECTOR OF ANTHROPOLOGY?AND TO HIRE A PROJECT ASSISTANT ARCHIVIST TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT A DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR THE DENVER MUSEUM OF NATURE & SCIENCE.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE MUSEUM&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;INVESTIGATE USER NEEDS AND DEVELOP A PLAN TO SELECT AND INSTALL A DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.&NBSP; ONCE INSTALLED, THE PROJECT TEAM&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;IDENTIFY A PILOT COLLECTION OF HUMANITIES ASSETS TO TEST AND ADJUST THE SYSTEM AS WELL AS DEVELOP WORKFLOWS, PERMISSIONS, AND ACCESS PROCEDURES FOR&NBSP;THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THE MUSEUM?S DIGITAL COLLECTIONS.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE RETENTION OF KEY STAFF POSITIONS AND THE&NBSP;INSTALLATION OF THE&NBSP;NEW DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;BENEFIT THE PRESERVATION OF, AND ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM?S 400,000 ARCHIVAL, ARCHAEOLOGICAL, AND ANTHROPOLOGICAL DIGITAL ASSETS.&NBSP;&NBSP;THE NEW SYSTEM&NBSP;WILL?ADDRESS THE MUSEUM?S PRIORITY TO?MANAGE AND MAKE MORE ACCESSIBLE DIGITAL COLLECTIONS?IN NORTH AMERICAN, OCEANIC, AND ASIAN ETHNOLOGY;?ARCHAEOLOGY; AND?THE?HUMANITIES IMAGE ARCHIVES, WHICH CONTAINS, FOR EXAMPLE,&NBSP;EARLY PHOTOGRAPHS OF NATIVE AMERICANS TAKEN BY?JESSE H. BRATLEY AND ROLAND REED,?EXHIBITION PROGRAMS, AND?FIELD?RESEARCH?MATERIALS.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE AUDIENCES THAT&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM?S DIGITAL COLLECTIONS&NBSP;WILL&NBSP;BE THE THOUSANDS OF&NBSP;ANNUAL&NBSP;VISITORS TO THE MUSEUM?S EXHIBITS;&NBSP;SCHOLARS STUDYING DIVERSE TOPICS IN ANTHROPOLOGY AND ARCHAEOLOGY; PARTICIPANTS OF VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING SUCH AS A PLANNED ?SCIENCE DIVISION LIVE? ONLINE PRESENTATION; AND&NBSP;STUDENTS AND THE PUBLIC.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO A CONSULTING FIRM EXPERIENCED IN HUMANITIES DIGITAL MANAGEMENT TO ASSIST IN THE PLANNING AND SELECTION OF A DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.&NBSP;]

SUSTAINABLE CURATION, PRESERVATION AND ONLINE ACCESS FOR MULTILINGUAL CULTURAL HERITAGE COLLECTIONS AT THE ARCHIVE OF THE INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES OF LATIN AMERICA [THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT AUSTIN'S ARCHIVE OF THE INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES OF LATIN AMERICA (AILLA) SEEKS AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN: HUMANITIES ORGANIZATIONS FUNDING TO SUSTAIN OPERATIONS AND SUPPORT FOR THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF ITS EXISTING NEH GRANT PD-260978-18 "ARCHIVING SIGNIFICANT COLLECTIONS OF ENDANGERED LANGUAGES: TWO MULTILINGUAL REGIONS OF NORTHWESTERN SOUTH AMERICA." THIS PROJECT WILL DIGITIZE, CURATE, AND ARCHIVE EIGHT SIGNIFICANT COLLECTIONS OF MULTILINGUAL, MULTIMEDIA MATERIALS THAT DOCUMENT INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES AND CULTURES FROM HIGHLAND ECUADOR AND THE UPPER RIO NEGRO REGION OF NORTHWEST BRAZIL AND EASTERN COLOMBIA. AS THE UNIVERSITY, THE COUNTRY, AND THE ENTIRE WORLD BEGIN THE DIFFICULT POST-PANDEMIC ECONOMIC RECOVERY, ARP SUPPORT WILL ENSURE AILLA'S CONTINUED GROWTH, DEVELOPMENT, LONG-TERM PRESERVATION, ACCESSIBILITY, AND DISCOVERABILITY BY SAFEGUARDING CRITICAL STAFF POSITIONS, WHICH ARE AT RISK OF BEING LOST.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RETAIN&NBSP;THE&NBSP;LANGUAGE DATA CURATOR AND HIRE&NBSP;A RESEARCH ASSISTANT&NBSP;TO&NBSP;SUPPORT PRESERVATION WORK FOR THE ARCHIVE OF THE INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES&NBSP;OF LATIN AMERICA&NBSP;(AILLA),&NBSP;A DIGITAL REPOSITORY OF RECORDINGS, TEXTS, IMAGES, AND OTHER MULTIMEDIA MATERIALS&NBSP;IN AND ABOUT INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES&NBSP;AND CULTURES OF LATIN AMERICA.&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;ARCHIVAL STAFF WILL&NBSP;CONTINUE TO ARRANGE&NBSP;AND CONTEXTUALIZE&NBSP;LINGUISTIC&NBSP;COLLECTIONS&NBSP;THAT COMPRISE FOUR LANGUAGE FAMILIES: EAST&NBSP;TUKANOAN,&NBSP;NADUHUP, ARAWAKAN, AND QUECHUAN.&NBSP;AMONG THE ACTIVITIES&NBSP;NEEDED TO PREPARE THE COLLECTIONS FOR&NBSP;USE FREE OF CHARGE&NBSP;ARE&NBSP;THE CREATION OF&NBSP;COLLECTION GUIDES&NBSP;WRITTEN IN BOTH ENGLISH AND SPANISH.&NBSP;IN ADDITION TO THIS WORK, STAFF WILL&NBSP;CONTINUE TO&NBSP;ASSIST USERS OF THE ARCHIVE TO FIND RESEARCH MATERIALS AND ACQUIRE PERMISSIONS TO WORK WITH THOSE MATERIALS; HELP RESEARCHERS&NBSP;PLAN FOR ARCHIVING INDIGENOUS LANGUAGE&NBSP;COLLECTIONS; AND&NBSP;WORK WITH INDIGENOUS GROUPS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THE US AND THROUGHOUT THE AMERICAS TO ARCHIVE THEIR OWN MATERIALS.&NBSP;&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE ARCHIVAL WORK CONDUCTED BY THE LANGUAGE DATA CURATOR AND RESEARCH ASSISTANT WILL MAKE ACCESSIBLE&NBSP;MULTIMEDIA&NBSP;COLLECTIONS&NBSP;THAT SPAN&NBSP;THE DISTINCT, MULTILINGUAL REGIONS COVERING&NBSP;HIGHLAND ECUADOR AND THE UPPER RIO NEGRO REGION OF NORTHWEST BRAZIL&NBSP;AND EASTERN COLOMBIA.&NBSP;THE STAFF WILL DEVELOP&NBSP;COLLECTION GUIDES IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH FOR FOUR COLLECTIONS, TWO OF WHICH WILL ALSO BE TRANSLATED INTO&NBSP;PORTUGUESE.&NBSP;&NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE COLLECTIONS OF THE ARCHIVE OF THE INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES OF LATIN AMERICA WILL&NBSP;BENEFIT&NBSP;INDIGENOUS&NBSP;PEOPLES&NBSP;IN THE AMERICAS, SCHOLARS, MEMBERS OF THE&NBSP;GENERAL PUBLIC, AND&NBSP;SPEAKERS OF THE REPRESENTED LANGUAGES THAT WILL HELP ENSURE THE LANGUAGES' SURVIVAL AND FLOURISHMENT.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

JESSE DREW HISTORICAL AND GENEALOGICAL ARCHIVES [IN 2017 NEH FUNDED A PRESERVATION ASSESSMENT GRANT TO THE FORT FAIRFIELD PUBLIC LIBRARY. WE ARE NOW READY WITH A PLAN TO IMPLEMENT MANY OF RECOMMENDATIONS MADE BY NORTHEAST DOCUMENT CONSERVATION CENTER. THIS PLAN CONSISTS OF REPLACEMENT OF THE STEP-LADDER WITH THE RE-INSTALLATION OF AN ORIGINAL TO THE TIME PERIOD LIBRARY LADDER. THIS INCREASES THE SAFETY FOR BOTH STAFF AND THE BOOKS DURING RETRIEVAL. ALSO INSTALLATION OF UV FILTER FILM ON WINDOWS; INSTALLATION OF SPACERS BETWEEN THE BOUND HISTORICAL NEWSPAPER BOOKS FOR AIR CIRCULATION TO PROTECT AND SUPPORT THE BINDINGS; AND LINING THE WOODEN SHELVING WITH ARCHIVAL SAFE MATERIAL TO PROTECT THE HISTORICAL BOOKS HOUSED ON THEM. THE JESSE DREW HISTORICAL ARCHIVES WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1925 UPON THE DEATH OF COL. FRANKLIN M. DREW WHO WILLED HIS ENTIRE HISTORICAL CIVIL WAR AND GENEALOGY LIBRARY TO OUR LIBRARY. MANY ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION ARE NOT AVAILABLE FOR RESEARCH ANYWHERE ELSE IN THE NORTHEAST.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN A PART-TIME ARCHIVAL AIDE AND TO IMPLEMENT PRESERVATION IMPROVEMENTS FOR HISTORICAL BOOKS AND THE COLLECTIONS OF THE JESSE DREW HISTORICAL ARCHIVES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THE LIBRARY PLANS TO ADD A LIBRARY LADDER, INSTALL UV FILTER FILM ON WINDOWS, INSTALL SPACERS BETWEEN BOUND NEWSPAPER BOOKS, AND LINE WOODEN SHELVES WITH PROTECTIVE MATERIAL.&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE&NBSP;GRANT WILL RETAIN KEY STAFF WHO SERVE AS FRONT-LINE CONTACTS FOR GENEALOGY AND RESEARCH REQUESTS AND INCREASE COLLECTIONS ACCESS BY BOTH PROTECTING THE COLLECTION AND ENABLING SAFER RETRIEVAL OF COLLECTION ITEMS.&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE&NBSP;AUDIENCES THAT WILL BENEFIT ARE RESEARCHERS AND THE LOCAL COMMUNITY.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT HAS NO PLANS TO SUBAWARD.&NBSP;&NBSP;]

FROM RESEARCH TO PRESENTATION: AN ORGANIZATIONAL QUEST TO SHARE NEW, UNTOLD, AND UNDERREPRESENTED STORIES OF OUR HOUSES AND COLLECTIONS THROUGH A NEW EXHIBITION [THE PRESERVATION SOCIETY OF NEWPORT COUNTY, IN NEWPORT, RHODE ISLAND, RESPECTFULLY REQUESTS A GRANT OF $498,415 TO CREATE THREE AND RETAIN SEVEN HUMANITIES POSITIONS TO SUPPORT THE RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, AND EXECUTION OF A NEW EXHIBITION AND FURTHER THE EFFORTS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF MUSEUM AFFAIRS TO ADVANCE THE HUMANITIES THROUGH RESEARCH AND SCHOLARSHIP OPPORTUNITIES. AN AWARD FROM THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE HUMANITIES WILL POSITION THE PRESERVATION SOCIETY TO REOPEN ITS EXHIBITION SPACE AND PRESENT A NEW EXHIBITION AND PROGRAMMING AS A PART OF THE ORGANIZATION'S EFFORT TO SHARE NEW, UNTOLD, AND UNDERREPRESENTED STORIES OF OUR HOUSES AND COLLECTIONS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN SEVEN POSITIONS WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF MUSEUM AFFAIRS AND ADD THREE POSITIONS, INCLUDING A&NBSP;SOCIAL&NBSP;HISTORY&NBSP;CURATOR,&NBSP;SPECIAL&NBSP;COLLECTIONS&NBSP;CURATOR, AND&NBSP;MUSEUM&NBSP;EDUCATOR, TO DEVELOP AN EXHIBITION LOCATED AT&NBSP;ROSECLIFF, ONE OF THE ELEVEN HISTORIC PROPERTIES OWNED AND CARED FOR BY THE PRESERVATION SOCIETY OF NEWPORT COUNTY.&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;MUSEUM STAFF WILL UNDERTAKE THE PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW EXHIBIT LOCATED AT&NBSP;ROSECLIFF, ONE OF THE GILDED AGE MANSIONS&NBSP;OF NEWPORT, RHODE ISLAND OPEN TO THE PUBLIC AS A HISTORIC HOUSE MUSEUM. AMONG THE ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THIS ENDEAVOR, THE&NBSP;SOCIAL&NBSP;HISTORY AND&NBSP;SPECIAL&NBSP;COLLECTIONS&NBSP;CURATORS, IN COLLABORATION WITH DEPARTMENT STAFF,&NBSP;WILL FOCUS ON THE HISTORIC OBJECTS AND STORIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE&NBSP;DIVERSITY OF&NBSP;INDIVIDUALS WHO DESIGNED, BUILT, AND WORKED AT THE MANSION.&NBSP;THE&NBSP;MUSEUM&NBSP;EDUCATOR&NBSP;WILL RESEARCH AND CREATE ACTIVITIES THAT REACH STUDENTS AND ADULTS ALIKE.&NBSP;&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE FINAL EXHIBITION AT&NBSP;ROSECLIFF&NBSP;WILL INCLUDE A PHYSICAL EXHIBIT, DIGITAL PRESENTATIONS, LECTURES, AND LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES THAT WILL BE ACCESSIBLE TO AUDIENCES OF ALL BACKGROUNDS.&NBSP;BEYOND THE EXHIBIT ITSELF, THIS PROGRAM WILL FEATURE IN-PERSON ACTIVITIES FOR YOUTH ATTENDEES BASED ON BROAD CURRICULUM STANDARDS, EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES, AND INFORMATIVE TOURS FOR MUSEUM STAFF TO EQUIP THEM WITH KNOWLEDGE TO SHARE WITH THE PUBLIC.&NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE HUMANITIES PROGRAMMING DEVELOPED FOR THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT&NBSP;AN ANTICIPATED AUDIENCE OF AT LEAST 25,000 INDIVIDUALS FROM ACROSS THE COUNTRY AND POTENTIALLY HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS MORE WHO PARTICIPATE IN THE SOCIETY?S VIRTUAL TOURS, LECTURES, AND OTHER EVENTS EVERY YEAR. THE SOCIETY OVERSEES 11 HISTORIC PROPERTIES, WHICH RECEIVED A TOTAL OF NEARLY&NBSP;ONE&NBSP;MILLION VISITORS ANNUALLY BEFORE THE PANDEMIC, AND AMONG THOSE VISITORS ARE RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

BRIDGING THE FINANCIAL IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AT THE MUNICIPAL ARCHIVES [THE NEW YORK CITY MUNICIPAL ARCHIVES, A DIVISION OF THE DEPARTMENT OF RECORDS AND INFORMATION SERVICES, REQUESTS PERSONNEL FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE APPRAISAL AND ACQUISITION ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE TRANSITION OF RECORDS AT THE END OF ELECTED OFFICIALS TERMS IN DECEMBER 2021, INCLUDING THE MAYOR, AND FOR IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL REFERENCE AND RESEARCH SERVICES.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS&NBSP;GRANT&NBSP;IS TO HIRE FOUR ARCHIVISTS TO COORDINATE THE APPRAISAL AND TRANSFER OF&NBSP;NEW YORK CITY&NBSP;GOVERNMENT RECORDS AND&NBSP;TO&NBSP;CONDUCT REFERENCE AND RESEARCH SERVICES FOR PATRONS.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;&NBSP;TWO HIRED APPRAISAL AND ACCESSIONS ARCHIVISTS WILL ASSIST IN THE TRANSFER OF RECORDS FROM THE CURRENT MAYORAL ADMINISTRATION BY: 1) CONDUCTING SURVEYS OF VARIOUS NEW YORK CITY AGENCIES AND OFFICES, 2) APPRAISING DIGITAL AND ANALOG FORMAT RECORDS FOR HISTORICAL VALUE, 3) FILING DOCUMENTATION ON THE TRANSFER OF COLLECTIONS, 4) HELPING TO COORDINATE THE TRANSFER OF DIGITAL COLLECTIONS TO CLOUD STORAGE ENVIRONMENTS, AND 5) PARTICIPATING IN CONTENT DEVELOPMENT FOR PROMOTING ARCHIVAL ACCESSIONS.&NBSP; TWO&NBSP;HIRED&NBSP;REFERENCE ARCHIVISTS WILL FIELD REFERENCE REQUESTS ONLINE AND IN PERSON, GUIDE PATRONS USING ACCESS TOOLS AND CATALOGS, AND RETRIEVE COLLECTIONS.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE&NBSP;APPRAISAL AND ACCESSIONS ARCHIVISTS WILL&NBSP;ASSIST IN&NBSP;THE COMPLETE AND ACCURATE TRANSFER&NBSP;AND ARCHIVAL PROCESSING&NBSP;OF HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT RECORDS FROM THE CURRENT MAYORAL ADMINISTRATION, WHICH NOTABLY WILL DOCUMENT KEY ACTIVITIES AND DECISIONS MADE DURING THE EARLY MONTHS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC WHEN THE CITY WAS AN EARLY EPICENTER.&NBSP; THE REFERENCE ARCHIVISTS WILL PROVIDE PATRONS OF THE MUNICIPAL ARCHIVES INFORMATION IN A TIMELY AND EFFICIENT MANNER&NBSP;BY MAKING RECORDS OF CITY GOVERNMENT AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC AND DEMONSTRATING EXPERTISE IN RESEARCH SERVICES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE ARCHIVAL RECORDS AND SERVICES SUPPORTED BY THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT THE TENS OF THOUSANDS OF ANNUAL USERS REPRESENTING DIVERSE LOCAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTIONS, SCHOLARS, STUDENTS, AUTHORS, RESEARCHERS, DOCUMENTARIANS,&NBSP;FAMILY&NBSP;AND COMMUNITY HISTORIANS, AS WELL AS THE GENERAL PUBLIC.&NBSP; THE ARCHIVES ALSO MAINTAINS&NBSP;ONGOING PARTNERSHIPS WITH THE NYC DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND LOCAL HIGHER-EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIALS FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.]

PRESERVATION AND ACCESS OF UNIQUE PUERTO RICAN AND CARIBBEAN STUDIES COLLECTIONS [THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO RIO PIEDRAS CAMPUS (UPR) REQUESTS FUNDING TO SUPPORT A ONE-YEAR PROJECT FOR DIGITAL PRESERVATION AND ACCESS OF SELECTED ITEMS IN UNIQUE COLLECTIONS RELATED TO PUERTO RICAN AND CARIBBEAN STUDIES HELD BY THE JOSE LAZARO MAIN LIBRARY AND THE COLLEGE OF HUMANITIES SEMINAR CENTERS. GIVEN THE HISTORICAL VALUE AND NEEDS FOR PRESERVATION THESE ITEMS, THEY HAVE A LIMITED CIRCULATION. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS LIMITED EVEN MORE THEIR PHYSICAL ACCESS. FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE REVITALIZATION AND DISSEMINATION OF THESE ITEMS AS DIGITAL OBJECTS TO MAKE THEM AVAILABLE FOR COLLEGE STUDENTS, PROFESSORS, RESEARCHERS, AND SCHOLARS AT LARGE DURING AND AFTER THE PANDEMIC. IT WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR COMPREHENSIVE STAFF TRAINING IN THE PLANNING AND DEPLOYMENT OF SUSTAINABLE, LONG TERM MEASURES IN MANAGING AND DISSEMINATION OF DIGITAL COLLECTIONS IN A FUTURE REOPENED ENVIRONMENT.] [PURPOSE:?THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS&NBSP;TO&NBSP;SUPPORT A DIGITAL PRESERVATION AND ACCESS PROJECT FOR UNIQUE&NBSP;PUERTO&NBSP;RICAN AND CARIBBEAN COLLECTIONS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF&NBSP;PUERTO&NBSP;RICO, RIO PIEDRAS CAMPUS.&NBSP;&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THIS GRANT WOULD SUPPORT&NBSP;STAFF AND EQUIPMENT PURCHASES TO DIGITIZE PRIORITY COLLECTIONS AND BEGIN DISSEMINATING&NBSP;THESE ITEMS&NBSP;FOR WIDER PUBLIC ACCESS.&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:?THIS GRANT WILL MAKE MORE OF THE UNIVERSITY'S COLLECTIONS AVAILABLE DURING THE IN-PERSON RESEARCH RESTRICTIONS OF THE PANDEMIC. IT WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR COMPREHENSIVE STAFF TRAINING IN THE PLANNING AND DEPLOYMENT OF SUSTAINABLE, LONG-TERM MEASURES IN MANAGEMENT AND DISSEMINATION OF DIGITAL COLLECTIONS IN A FUTURE REOPENED ENVIRONMENT.&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT&NBSP;PROFESSORS, RESEARCHERS, AND SCHOLARS AT LARGE DURING AND AFTER THE PANDEMIC.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:?THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

STRENGTHENING DISTANCE LEARNING FOR INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC [THE NORTHWEST INDIAN LANGUAGE INSTITUTE AND THE NATIONAL BREATH OF LIFE ARCHIVAL INSTITUTE FOR INDIGENOUS LANGUAGES SHARE A COMMON MISSION TO SUPPORT INDIGENOUS LANGUAGE RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE UNITED STATES. THESE INSTITUTES ENDEAVOR TO INCREASE CAPACITY WITHIN NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITIES FOR THE PRESERVATION OF THEIR UNIQUE CULTURAL, HISTORICAL, AND LINGUISTIC HERITAGE. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTED THE ABILITY OF BOTH INSTITUTES TO CARRY OUT THEIR WORK, WHICH IS PRIMARILY ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH IN-PERSON TRAININGS. IN THE PAST YEAR, BOTH PROGRAMS HAVE PIVOTED TOWARD ONLINE LEARNING AND ON-DEMAND TRAININGS TO CONTINUE A MODIFIED VERSION OF NORMAL OPERATIONS, EXPAND PROGRAM ACCESSIBILITY, AND MEET THE VARYING NEEDS OF PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS. THIS PROJECT SEEKS FUNDING TO SUPPORT HUMANITIES POSITIONS AND TO BUILD UPON THE EMERGING ONLINE EXPERIENCE AND RESOURCES TO CREATE A ROBUST CATALOG OF DISTANCE LEARNING OFFERINGS THAT FOLLOW BEST PRACTICES IN ONLINE PEDAGOGY.] [PURPOSE:?THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS&NBSP;TO SUPPORT TWO INDIGENOUS LANGUAGE INSTITUTES WITHIN THE&NBSP;UNIVERSITY OF&NBSP;OREGON&NBSP;THAT ENCOURAGE INDIGENOUS LANGUAGE RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE UNITED STATES.&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THIS GRANT WOULD SUPPORT&NBSP;FACULTY AND LANGUAGE EXPERTS WHO WILL PIVOT LANGUAGE LEARNING AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES&NBSP;TOWARD ONLINE LEARNING AND ON-DEMAND ONLINE TRAININGS&NBSP;DUE TO THE CONTINUED EFFECTS AND LIMITATIONS OF THE PANDEMIC.&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:?THIS GRANT WOULD ALLOW THE&NBSP;LANGUAGE INSTITUTES TO CONTINUE A MODIFIED VERSION OF NORMAL OPERATIONS, EXPAND PROGRAM ACCESSIBILITY, AND MEET THE VARYING NEEDS OF PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS.&NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL&NBSP;BENEFIT LOCAL RESIDENTS WHO RELY ON INDIGENOUS LANGUAGE PROGRAMS AS WELL AS A NATIONAL AUDIENCE&NBSP;WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM THE DIGITIZED LESSONS AND TRAININGS.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:?THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

GATEWAY TO PRIDE: LBGTQIA+ COLLECTING INITIATIVE AT THE MISSOURI HISTORICAL SOCIETY [THE MISSOURI HISTORICAL SOCIETY REQUESTS NEH ARP SUPPORT TO RETAIN FULL- AND PART-TIME STAFF TO ENSURE CONTINUATION OF THE GATEWAY TO PRIDE INITIATIVE, A REGION-WIDE LGBTQIA+ COLLECTING INITIATIVE LED BY MEMBERS OF THE ST. LOUIS LGBTQIA+ COMMUNITY. NEH SUPPORT WILL HELP MAINTAIN OUR FULL-TIME LGBTQIA+ COLLECTIONS CURATORIAL ASSISTANT AND THREE PAID, PART-TIME GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANTS. THESE ROLES PERFORM THE ESSENTIAL WORK OF GATEWAY TO PRIDE: RESEARCH, ACQUISITIONS, COLLECTING ORAL HISTORIES, CATALOGING, PROCESSING, ARCHIVES, AND PUBLIC AWARENESS TO CONTINUE THIS ONGOING INITIATIVE TO DOCUMENT AND SHARE OUR REGION'S LGBTQIA+ HISTORY.] [PURPOSE:'THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ENSURE CONTINUATION OF THE GATEWAY TO PRIDE INITIATIVE, A REGION-WIDE LGBTQIA+ COLLECTING INITIATIVE LED BY MEMBERS OF THE ST. LOUIS, MISSOURI LGBTQIA+ COMMUNITY.&NBSP;  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THIS GRANT WOULD RETAIN STAFF TO ACQUIRE AND RESEARCH NEW COLLECTIONS, COLLECT ORAL HISTORIES, AND CATALOG AND PROCESS AN ARCHIVAL BACKLOG TO DOCUMENT AND SHARE REGIONAL LGBTQIA+ HISTORY.&NBSP;  EXPECTED OUTCOMES:'THIS GRANT WOULD REVAMP THE GATEWAY TO PRIDE INITIATIVE AND ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO EXPAND THEIR COLLECTION AND CONTINUE DIGITIZING AND MAKING ACCESSIBLE LGBTQIA+ ARCHIVES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT LOCAL RESIDENTS AS WELL AS NATIONAL RESEARCHERS AND LEARNERS OF LGBTQIA+ HISTORY.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:'THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

COMMUNITY HISTORY IN SOUTH ALABAMA: PRESERVING AND SHARING STORIES OF MINORITIZED ALABAMIANS [WE PROPOSE TO FUND TWO PROJECTS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH ALABAMA TO SUPPORT THE PRESERVATION AND DISSEMINATION OF COMMUNITY HISTORY OF MINORITIZED CITIZENS IN OUR AREA. FUNDING FROM THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN WILL HELP TO RESUME WORK ON PROJECTS AFFECTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. FUNDING FOR POSITIONS AT THE MCCALL RARE BOOK & MANUSCRIPT LIBRARY WILL FACILITATE PROGRESS ON THE HISTORY, HUMANITIES, COMMUNITY, & JUSTICE IN ALABAMA PROJECT, COORDINATED BY THE UNIVERSITY HONORS COLLEGE. ONGOING EFFORTS BY A NUMBER OF FACULTY ON COMMUNITY ORAL HISTORIES HAVE RESULTED IN A BACKLOG OF TRANSCRIPTION AND ARCHIVAL WORK ON TOPICS INCLUDING: AFRICATOWN AND DESCENDANTS OF ENSLAVED AFRICANS BROUGHT TO THE AREA ON THE CLOTILDA; MARDI GRAS AND THE LGBTQ COMMUNITY; MOBILE'S JEWISH COMMUNITY; AND SEVERAL OTHERS. THE USA ARCHAEOLOGY MUSEUM WILL FUND AN EXHIBITION ON ARTIFACTS, ORAL HISTORIES, AND MUSIC RECORDINGS FROM HISTORIC AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITIES, AND INCLUDES TRAVELING AND EDUCATION COMPONENTS.] [PURPOSE:&NBSP;THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RETAIN AND HIRE STAFF AT BOTH THE MCCALL LIBRARY AND THE USA ARCHEOLOGY MUSEUM TO PROCESS AND DIGITIZE ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS AT THE LIBRARY AND TO PRODUCE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, AN EXHIBIT, AND PROGRAMMING AT THE MUSEUM.&NBSP;&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE STAFF WOULD PROCESS AND DIGITIZE ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS AT THE MCCALL RARE BOOK AND MANUSCRIPT LIBRARY AND TO DEVELOP TRAVELING, WEBSITE-BASED, AND PERMANENT EXHIBITS AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS IN CONSULTATION WITH HUMANITIES SCHOLARS AT THE USA ARCHEOLOGY MUSEUM.&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:&NBSP;THE&NBSP;EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE THE PRESERVATION, INTERPRETATION, AND DISSEMINATION OF COMMUNITY HISTORY PERTAINING TO MOBILE, ALABAMA ON SUCH SUBJECTS AS URBAN RENEWAL, AFRICAN-AMERICAN ENTREPRENEURSHIP, THE JEWISH COMMUNITY OF THE REGION, AND OTHER SUBJECTS.&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, SCHOLARS, THE COMMUNITY, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WOULD BENEFIT FROM THE PROJECT TO MAKE THE ORAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS AND EXHIBITS ACCESSIBLE ONLINE WHILE LOCAL POPULATIONS WOULD BENEFIT FROM THE ON-SITE EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMMING AT THE MUSEUM.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:&NBSP;THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;&NBSP;]

LINCOLNVILLE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PROJECT [THIS PROJECT WILL FACILITATE THE ORGANIZATION OF THE PHYSICAL AND DIGITAL COLLECTION OF THE LINCOLNVILLE MUSEUM AND CULTURAL CENTER. A MORE COMPLETE HISTORY OF AMERICA: DEVELOPING ARABIC OCR TO TELL THE STORY OF ARABS IN AMERICA [NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY SEEKS SUPPORT TO COMPLETE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A TEXT SEARCHABLE OPEN SOURCE ARCHIVE OF HISTORICAL ARAB AMERICAN NEWSPAPERS, BOOKS AND MANUSCRIPTS, COMPLETE WITH INTERACTIVE ANALYTIC CAPACITY. THIS ONGOING PROJECT WAS CRITICALLY DISRUPTED BY COVID-19 AT A TIME WHEN DEMAND FOR ONLINE ARCHIVES AND ADVANCED SEARCH CAPABILITY HAS EXPONENTIALLY INCREASED. CREATING THIS RESOURCE THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF OCR FOR ARABIC TEXT AND HANDWRITING, AND THE DIGITIZATION OF MATERIALS WILL ADVANCE OUR CENTER'S MISSION BY BRINGING TO LIGHT THE HIDDEN HISTORY OF 150 YEARS OF ARAB IMMIGRATION TO THE US, AND ARAB AMERICAN CULTURAL, ECONOMIC AND POLITICAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO AMERICA. THIS CUTTING EDGE TOOL, AND THE UNPRECEDENTED RESEARCH IT MAKES POSSIBLE, WILL ALLOW SCHOLARS TO TELL THE STORIES OF A LONG UNDER-REPRESENTED COMMUNITY, ITS ENCOUNTER WITH RACE IN AMERICA, AND HOW IT HELPED CHANGE THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE THROUGH ITS PRESENCE AND ACTIVISM ON VARIOUS FRONTS.] [PURPOSE:'THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP OPTICAL CHARACTER RECOGNITION (OCR) TECHNOLOGY FOR ARABIC TEXT AND HANDWRITING THAT WOULD ENABLE A TEXT SEARCHABLE ARCHIVE OF HISTORICAL ARAB AMERICAN SOURCES FOR A RESEARCH CENTER AT&NBSP;NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY.&NBSP; ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:&NBSP;THIS GRANT&NBSP;WOULD SUPPORT&NBSP;DEVELOPERS&NBSP;TO FINISH THE OCR APPLICATION FOR ARABIC TEXT AND HANDWRITING AS WELL AS THE DIGITIZATION OF HUNDREDS&NBSP;OF&NBSP;THOUSANDS OF ARAB AMERICAN TEXTS.&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:'THIS GRANT WOULD&NBSP;ALLOW THE RESEARCH CENTER TO COMPLETE TECHNOLOGY THAT WOULD BE AN INNOVATIVE ADDITION TO RECENT HUMANITIES INITIATIVES IN DIGITIZING AND MAKING ACCESSIBLE HANDWRITTEN ARABIC TEXTS.&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE BROADER ARAB AMERICAN RESEARCH COMMUNITY AND THE PUBLIC WHO WISH TO SEARCH AND DISCOVER ARAB AMERICAN TEXTS AND SOURCES.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:'THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

AILEY CHOREOGRAPHIC LEGACY PROJECT [FUNDS FROM THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE HUMANITIES WOULD SUPPORT THE NEXT STAGE OF THE ALVIN AILEY CHOREOGRAPHIC LEGACY PROJECT?AN INITIATIVE TO CATALOG AND DIGITIZE SELECT WORKS IN THE AILEY REPERTORY FOR THE PURPOSE OF RESTAGING, HISTORIC PRESERVATION, AND THE EVENTUAL LAUNCH OF A LICENSING PROGRAM FOR PROFESSIONAL DANCE COMPANIES AND UNIVERSITIES?INCLUDING SALARIES FOR AILEY?S PROJECT DIRECTOR, ARCHIVIST, ARCHIVES CONSULTANT, PROJECT COORDINATOR, AND VIDEOGRAPHER/FILM EDITOR TO CONTINUE PRIORITIZING THIS EFFORT. IT WOULD ALSO ALLOW THE THEATER TO EVENTUALLY LAUNCH&NBSP;A LICENSING PROGRAM FOR PROFESSIONAL DANCE COMPANIES AND UNIVERSITIES.&NBSP;  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT&NBSP;STUDENTS, RESEARCHERS, AND SUPPORTERS OF THE ALVIN AILEY THEATER, ALLOWING LEGACY PERFORMANCES TO BE STUDIED AND RECREATED.&NBSP;  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:?THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

THE COLLECTION OF 500 WORDS AND PHRASES AND SIMPLE CONVERSATIONS BETWEEN SPEAKERS WILL BE USED TO CREATE A WEBSITE FOR L/DAKOTA LANGUAGE LEARNERS.&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:?THIS GRANT WOULD&NBSP;SUPPORT&NBSP;L/DAKOTA LANGUAGE LEARNING AMONG NATIVE AMERICAN YOUTH, AN IMPORTANT STEP IN PRESERVING AND REVITALIZING A&NBSP;CRITICALLY ENDANGERED&NBSP;LANGUAGE.&NBSP;&NBSP; INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:&NBSP;THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT&NBSP;L/DAKOTA LANGUAGE&NBSP;LEARNERS, PARTICULARLY&NBSP;L/DAKOTA YOUTH, BUT ALSO NON-TRIBAL LANGUAGE LEARNERS.&NBSP; SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES:?THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.&NBSP;]

REGIS MOHAWK TRIBE. THEY WILL ALSO CREATE PUBLIC PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITIONS.&NBSP; EXPECTED OUTCOMES:?THIS GRANT WOULD ALLOW THE&NBSP;MUSEUM TO MAKE PRIMARY SOURCES MORE ACCESSIBLE,&NBSP;AND TO CONDUCT MORE RESEARCH TO MAKE FORT TICONDEROGA MORE ENGAGING.
